smell_analysis.justification: All provided diagram pages contain meaningful content and elements.
All use cases in the diagrams (Pages 2 and 3) are associated with actors, either directly or via <<include>> relationships from use cases that have actors.
No instances of multiple use cases describing the same activity with the same actor were found.
No distinct model elements with the same name were found within the same package/namespace context on the provided diagrams.
The database schemas (Pages 14-19) appear to be normalized. No obvious redundant data columns without foreign keys were identified.
All use case names consistently use the imperative verb form (e.g., 'Vaata', 'Tuvasta', 'Registreeri').
In the state diagram (Page 9), all states (Ootel, Aktiivne, Mitteaktiivne, Unustatud, LÃµpetatud) are reachable from the Start node.
In the activity diagram (Page 4), all actions are connected in a flow that leads from the start to the end.
All visible relationships on class and database diagrams (e.g., Pages 5, 6, 12, 14) have multiplicity indicators (e.g., 1, 0..*) at both ends.
No single diagram page contains 10 or more central elements. The densest diagram (Page 15) has 9 tables.
No single class or table has 6 or more visual connection lines on a single page. The class 'auto' on Page 12 has 5 connections.
The layout of elements in all diagrams is reasonably uniform; no related elements are placed excessively far apart compared to the average distance.
All use cases and activity actions start with an active verb (e.g., 'Vaata', 'Otsi', 'Vali').
All element names (Classes, Tables, Attributes) are longer than 3 characters (e.g., 'Isik', 'Riik', 'auto', 'kood').
The class named 'auto' (found on Page 5 'Kontseptuaalne eskiismudel', Page 11, and Page 12) starts with a lowercase letter, violating the convention that class names should be capitalized.
All attributes and columns start with lowercase letters as required.
No standard Hungarian notation or type prefixes (like 'tbl_', 'str_') were found on classes, tables, or attributes. 'AK_' is used for constraints, which does not violate the rule for element names.
